Umm, buy a code coverage tool.

Off the top of my head:

www.metamata.com - last time I tried it, it died on my code
www.sitraka.com  - I think this is the one I successfully tested in
November on our code

There was one other I tested, but I can't remember the vendor.

I think metamata use byte code rewriting. At least one of the tools I
evaluated used source code rewriting and basically did what your tech
lead proposed you do manually. Personally, I think you'd be nuts to do
it manually. At the very least, grab a Java parser and rewrite it to
spit out instrumented Java source.

I don't think any of the tools would detect the situation where an
Exception is not caught in the code and no test caused it to be thrown.
This might happen with either RuntimeException or with a method that
declares some exceptions in its throw clause and allows them to
propagate up. In fact, I'm pretty sure one can't detect that in the
general case.

e.g. the code below if never called with null foo, could still result
in 100% coverage. The theoretical way to handle this in the coverage
tool is to add an edge to the control flow graph for each possible
exception, but since RuntimeException and Error aren't declared in the
throws clause....

public void mightGetNullPointerException(Object foo) {
  if (foo.equals(this.myFoo)) {
    // ...
  }
}

Regards,

Rob
